entry.title: Setup Fiori Launchpad Notifications for SAP Business Workflow
entry.content:
This blog post describes the setup to receive notifications from workitems sent by SAP Business Workflow in SAP Fiori Launchpad (bell icon):

This blog post copies the text from the official documentation Enabling Push Notifications (SAP Business Workflow) | SAP Help Portal. and it's enriched with a few screenshots taken from the blog post Fiori Launchpad - Notification Configuration - SAP Community.

 

Important prerequisite

You have enabled the Notification Channel (see: Notification Channel Configuration (Fiori Launchpa... - SAP Community), otherwise you can't use the notifications in SAP Fiori Launchpad.

 

Activating Your Task Provider for Push Notifications (link to SAP Help Portal)

Activate your task provider to enable push notifications in the SAP Fiori style for your workflows in SAP Business Workflow.

Context

You have to activate your task provider once, so that the Provider button in transaction SWF_PUSH_NOTIF1 turns green. Only then can you configure your application to enable push notifications.

Procedure

Call transaction SPRO and start the SAP Reference IMG.

Search for Notification.

Select the entry Notification Channel Provider Enablement.

  1. Choose Administration > Notification Provider Settings > Register Notification Providers.
    Be careful, the entries are sorted by Line number, not by Provider ID.
    If the provider ID SAP_BUSINESS_WORKFLOW exists, skip this activity:


    If it doesn't exist, create it:
    1. For Notification Provider ID, enter SAP_BUSINESS_WORKFLOW.
    2. For Provider Class, enter CL_SWF_PUSH_NOTIF_PROVIDER.
    3. For Description, enter a description.
  2. Choose Administration > Notification Provider Settings > Manage Notification Providers.
    1. Choose New Entries, select SAP_BUSINESS_WORKFLOW, and activate it.



      Choose Save.

Results

Your provider button in transaction SWF_PUSH_NOTIF1 is now green.

 

Configuring Your Application for Push Notifications (link to SAP Help Portal)

Configure your application to enable push notifications in the SAP Fiori style for your workflows in SAP Business Workflow.

Prerequisites

  • Your provider button in transaction SWF_PUSH_NOTIF1 is green. For more information, see Activating Your Task Provider for Push Notifications.

  • You have WF_Admin authorization.

Procedure

  1. Call transaction SWF_PUSH_NOTIF1.
  2. Change to edit mode.
  3. Choose Create New Entry.
  4. Choose the task or the workflow step that you want to create notifications for.
    1. For a task, you do not need to maintain Version and Step.
    2. For a workflow step, you have to maintain Version with the definition version, and you have to maintain Step.
      Note

      The definition version is usually 0000. For major changes only (for example, there is a new alternative for a user decision), you can define an entry with a new original version to separate the configuration for the old and new workflow instances. You can create the new version with the Copy button.

  5. The text for Object Name is entered automatically.
  6. Set the Active flag.
    Note

    To disable notifications, remove the flag.

    Recommendation

    We recommend that you disable all notifications before transporting.

  7. Optional: You can group tasks to be executed at the same time, and send just one push notification for the group. If you want the notifications for a task to be grouped on the notifications UI, set the Groupable flag.
  8. Choose Actions.
    1. Enter an Action Text.
    2. If you have set the Groupable flag, enter an Action Text for Mass Execution.
    3. Optional: By default, actions can be executed directly from push notifications. If you want to prevent them from being executable, select the Hidden checkbox.
    4. You can configure the style of the button for the actions.
  9. Choose Texts.
    1. Configure a notification text without exposing sensitive information.
    2. Configure a notification text including sensitive information.
    3. Configure a text to display when notifications are grouped for mass execution.
  10. To delete existing entries and therefore no longer send notifications, choose Remove Selected Entries.
  11. Choose Save.

Next Steps

To make the changes you have made to your workflow visible in your SAP Fiori launchpad, you must refresh the cache in transaction /IWNGW/H_CLEAR_CACHE:

  • Clear Metadata Cache:
    • This clears all notification metadata, which includes notification type texts and action texts so that the latest values can be fetched from notification provider during callback. The admin can clear the metadata in two ways:
  • Clear Data Cache
    • This clears the notification properties applied to templates and encrypted secure notification properties so that the latest values can be fetched from notification provider during callback.


 

Tips about Workflow setup

SAP Business Workflow is complex, so in general, ask a workflow expert in case something doesn't work.

Just in case you can't immediately reach an expert, if it "doesn't work at all", according to me, the most important activities to check are those two ones:

  1. Workflow Basic Customizing | SAP Help Portal otherwise workflow can't start at all (transaction SCU3, to be done once per client)
  2. Configure Workflow Tasks | SAP Help Portal to classify the standard tasks, otherwise no "agent" receives the workitems/notifications (transaction PFTS > Create classification > General task)

Example for checking the agents:

Transaction SWI1 (display all workflow workitems) > select one > Workflow log:

Agents:

Potential agents:

The message "All users can process this task" (WL320) means that the task is a General Task. 

The actual agents are the ones obtained from the intersection of Agents and Potential agents. Here, only Sandra will receive the workitem and a notification.

To classify the task 02000070 as General Task, run the transaction PFTS, display the task, then menu Additional data > Classification > Create:

entry.title: Re: Node.js @sap/hana-client 2.25.29 getting strange erro...
entry.content: Hello, @SAP/hana-client v2.26.18 has been released, and it includes the fix for this issue. In the meanwhile, if `mscrypto` is still the desired crypto lib that you would like to use, it's recommended to keep `sslCryptoProvider=mscrypto` to ensure `mscrypto` is used.

entry.title: Switching to Spaces and Pages Experience Sharing – Changing Page Tile Colors on My Home Page
entry.content:
Introduction

It has been a while since I touched the topic of Spaces and Pages in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Today I am going to continue my series on Spaces and Pages – Changing Page Tile Colors.

Recently one user raised a question:  In the News and Pages section of My Home page, those page tiles were colorful. However, after the 2508 upgrade, they became mono color.  I am going to explain what happened and the steps to bring back the colors and transport this UI change to the Test and Production tenants in a 3 System Landscape.

 

Background

The user sees two different sets of Page Tiles below, one is the mono color after 2508 Upgrade, and another one is the colorful tiles before upgrade in the Starter System which you usually don’t upgrade.

 Mono Color Page Tiles on a 2508 System

 Colorful Tiles on a Starter System (Prior to 2508 Release)

When we talk about these Page Tile colors, a few things need to keep in mind:

  • When a system is delivered or upgraded, the original color is set by the developers. The original color could be gray as shown above if nobody changes it.
  • System administrator can change the colors of these Page Tiles. This color change impacts to all users.  Individual users cannot change the Page Tile color.
  • The color change is part of Key User UI Adaptation effort.

In the next section, I am going to detail the steps to change the Page Tile colors.

 

Steps to Change Page Tile Color

Below figure is my News and Pages section in the Dev tenant.  There are six Page Tiles, only one tile “Customers and Products” has a default gray color.  The remaining five tiles are all colorful.

Six Page Tiles in News and Pages Section

 To Change the title color, we will take the Key User UI Adaptation route.  You can see some explanations in SAP Help Portal, Adapting the UI.

You go to the User Action Menu, select Adapt UI.  Click on the OK button when you see an Info message pop-up: “You have personalized the app or there are public views.  The app is reloading without these changes”.  It might take a few more seconds until you see the below figure which has “UI Adaptation – Navigation – Visualization” in the Title Bar. 

Note 1: At current 2508 release, the UI Adaptation Tool is still not 100% compatible with the Fiori Launchpad. So, you might have to click on “Adapt UI” user menu for the 2nd time to enter the UI Adaptation Tool. This situation will improve in a later release.

Note 2: The pop-up message means for My Home page, there are already changes made by users. The system is going to bring up the app with different versions.

Note 3: The Version History is working, but not robust yet. If you switch to an old version, try to refresh the screen  in your web browser to bring the setting from the server to the frontend. I will talk about it  more later.

Now you click on the right mouse button, the pop-up button Personalize My Home shows up.

UI Adaptation Mode

 Clicking on Personalize My Home button, My Home Settings window pops up. Then expand News and Pages menu in My Home Settings window. Now Edit News and Pages window pops up.

My Home Settings Window

 Expanding the Spaces and Pages menu, you get the Edit Pages window. Here you can scroll up and down in the left panel titled Spaces and Pages to find the page tile you are interested in. For example, I find the Space Internal Sales, Page Sales Processing. By selecting this page, I can change its tile color to one of 10 available colors shown on the right hand side.

Change the Color of a Page Tile

 You might notice that Internal Sales Overview Page Tile has a green color in My Home page, but it shows the gray color on the list. That’s because the developers changed the tile color before its release, the original color (not the default color) is green. The gray color in the list indicates it is still the original color, not touched by the Key User; it could be red or green; or even gray like Page Customers and Products, since the developers leave the default color there as the original color.

After you select the color, click the Close button in the Edit Pages window.  Then click the Save button in the My Home Settings button.

When you come back to the UI Adaptation window, you notice the Sales Processing tile has changed the color.  Also, there is a Draft text in the Version History area.  By expanding the Version History, you can see the entire history of this UI Adaptation.  My current version is still in Draft state, Unpublished. 

Draft State of UI Adaptation

 If you cannot make the final decision on your change, you can save your Draft by clicking the Save button on the right-hand side in the title bar. Keep in mind that other Key Users can edit your draft version change as well. It creates an opportunity to the team work.

Next step of changing the color of a tile is to Activate it by clicking on the button to the right.

The Activation Button of the UI Adaptation Tool

A new window Activate New Version pops up. Try to give a meaningful title and easy for you to find it later in the Version History. I enter “Change color of Sales Processing tile”.  Then, hit the Confirm button.

Give a Name to the New Version

 Now the Version History text changed from “Draft” to “Change color of Sales Processing tile” in green and a Truck icon appears. A new version is born.  You use the Truck icon to publish this UI Adaptation so that all end users can use it.  In addition, you can export this UI Adaptation to your Test and Production tenants.

The Publish Button of the UI Adaptation Tool

After the publication, hit the X button on the right of the UI Adaptation Tool Bar to exit from the tool. Then another pop-up window shows.  It basically tells you that the screen will be refreshed to load your latest version.

Info Pop-Up Window “App Requires Reload”

 

Switch Back to Old Color

Sometimes we need to reverse our work, for example, some end users don’t like the changes we made. This is possible.

To do this, you select an older version from the Version History dropdown list. Refresh the screen to see exactly what old color is! Otherwise, you still see the latest version.  In my example, I selected the very original version called "Original App". Now the Page Tile Sales Processing is changed back to its original color of gray.

Bring back the Original Color

 A little different from our normal understanding, we need to create a new version based on the old version, not just reactivate an old version. Only the version at the top of the Version History can be active, and you cannot move up an old version to the top.  So, when you click on the Activate New Version button, a Reactivate Version window pops up.

Enter Text for Reactivate Version

 Check the Version History, a new version Reverse to Original App is there.  I still need to publish it so that all end users can use it.

The Version History Dropdown List

 

Transport Your Change to the Test and Production Tenants

I have written a blog on Transport Your Spaces and Pages Configurations in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud 3-System Landscape Systems.  It explains all the details of creating and delivering a transport.

After I create a new Software Collection called Page Tile Adaptation, I need to add content to it by clicking the Add Item button. 

Software Collection Page Tile Adaptation

 When you search which content to be added to your UI Adaptation Export Collection, use the filter Type “UI Flexibility: Views and Changes (UIFLEX_CD)”, you should be able to find your content.

Set Filter Type as “UI Flexibility: Views and Changes (UIFLEX_CD)”

 If you make several changes to this Page Tile as I did in this blog, i.e., assigning a color, then reverse it back to the original color, there is only one content item S/4HANA Product Home.

Add an UI Adaptation Content to an Export Software Collection

 After adding the content to the Software Collection, I click on the Inventory button to find out what’s inside.

Add Content Item S/4HANA Product Home to the Software Collection Page Tile Adaptation

The Inventory button opens a Change History of the Content Item S/4HANA Product Home.  Within two days of writing this blog, I made changes four times until assigning this collection to the Software Collection Page Tile Adaptation.

List of All Changes Made to the Content Item S/4HANA Product Home

 

Conclusion

As an administrator, you can change the color of the Page Tiles in My Home page for all users by using the Key User UI Adaptation tool.  You can bring the colorful page tiles back to your My Home page.

 

References

  • Transport Your Spaces and Pages Configurations in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud 3-System Landscape Systems
  • Switching to Spaces and Pages Experience Sharing – My Three Best Practices of Using Spaces and Pages
  • Switching to Spaces and Pages Experience Sharing - Deploying Spaces and Pages Best Practices
  • Switching to Spaces and Pages Experience Sharing - Assigning Predefined S&P to Your Own Biz Roles
  • Switching to Spaces and Pages Experience Sharing - Using Display Security Audit Log Fiori App

entry.title: SAPinsider EMEA 2025 in Three Easy Steps
entry.content:
Returning for a third year in succession, SAPinsider EMEA 2025 will open it’s doors at the Tivoli Hotel in Copenhagen next week on 1st October. And I know that the SAP team is all set and ready to go, having spent the past few months working on content and exhibition planning for this annual conference.

And with the inside scoop on our session plan this year, I also know that we have a lot to talk about and share with the many SAP customers and business partners who are planning to attend this year. So l for one am looking forward to our third outing here, in the charming city of Copenhagen.

So, in what has now become an annual event in itself, I am writing this blog to give you a sneak peek of SAP’s conference plans, and how to make the most of the event in three easy steps. And yes, of course, this will include details of my personal top picks for must-see SAP sessions!  

Step 1: Plan Ahead

As a conference attendee you’ll be invited to download the latest SAPinsider event app before you travel to Copenhagen, so my advice is do install this before you go and then spend some time whilst travelling selecting sessions and adding them to your personal agenda. Don’t leave this until you get there – you'll find yourself busy with sessions and conversations, and very little time for planning. So pre-planning is always best, and then you’ll arrive with a purpose, and ready to make the most of the educational and networking opportunities available.

To give you a head-start, here are some ideas for sessions to see, and my personal top picks:

  1. The keynotes – yes, both of them! In the day 1 keynote, SAP’s Jorrit de Groot will share insights on how customers are partnering with SAP to leverage SAP Business Suite to overcome key business challenges. On day 2 the keynote will focus on NOVO Nordisk’s experience of their own transition to SAP S/4HANA. With lots of practical advice offered in both keynote sessions, I’m sure these will be of great interest to anyone considering or already involved in their own business transformation project.
  2. Conference sessions. There’s a lot to choose from, however here are five sessions from the SAP team to add to your agenda:
    1. Transforming Finance with AI: What's Here, What's Next, and How to Prepare
    2. AI Won't Take Your Job—But Someone Using It Might
    3. Unlocking Growth and Agility with SAP's Two-Tier Cloud ERP Model
    4. SAP Business Data Cloud: Product Overview, Updates, and Roadmap
    5. SAP Integration Suite: Product Strategy, Innovations, and Roadmap
  3. Hands-on-Labs. Get up close and personal with SAP solutions, in these three sessions:
    1. Extend SAP S/4HANA (Cloud ERP) with SAP Build While Keeping the Core Clean
    2. Modernize Enterprise Integrations Across Hybrid Landscapes with SAP Integration Suite
    3. The SAP Security Game

And of course there are many other sessions, including customer case stories, listed on the event agenda too.

Step 2: Network with peers and industry experts

Another “not to be missed” opportunity at SAPinsider is the chance to network with industry peers, SAP business partners and the SAP team. This event never fails to deliver as an excellent networking opportunity, and I for one will be taking my time to make the most of it.

In terms of networking, I along with several colleagues will be helping to support the SAP exhibit booth at the event this year, so why not come along to say hello and have a chat at our new-look exhibit booth? We're really looking forward to having some great conversations with event attendees this year, so please don’t be shy, join us at the SAP booth and ask any questions you might have…and in addition you can also voice your opinion too, as we’re once again offering you the chance to tell us what you think about SAP solutions, as we’re partnering again with Trust Radius, who will be taking product reviews at the SAP booth too.

Step 3: Make the most of your free time…but continue those conversations!

Conference days are busy, and if you make the most of them you’ll find yourself in need of some rest and relaxation…but not too much of course, you’re still there to work after all! So if you're thinking of using the free time you have to take in the sights, sounds and tastes of Copenhagen, then why not consider planning for some out of conference meetings with colleagues, peers, partners and the SAP team when they’re “off the clock”, and continue your networking conversations over evening dinner, or whilst taking that stroll by the Nyhavn Canal.

See you there!

For those of you travelling to Copenhagen, I do hope that you find SAPinsider EMEA 2025 to be a truly rewarding experience. Remember to take time to create an agenda in the event app, and of course if you visit the show floor then look me up at the SAP exhibit booth.

Safe travels and see you in Copenhagen!

Chris Grundy

Product Marketing, SAP BTP

entry.title: Custom CDS - Modification After Publishing - S4 Public cloud
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

In S/4HANA Public Cloud, we are working with a CDS view that serves as a primary data source and is referenced by multiple other CDS views.

Now, I need to make some modifications in the join conditions of this base CDS. However, when attempting this, the system asks me to first delete the references from the dependent CDS views before making changes. This would result in a significant impact on our current setup.

Is there any way to modify the base CDS join conditions without having to remove all the references from the dependent CDS views?

Additionally, since we are implementing this for a 100-client setup, I would like to know if it is possible to access and modify this CDS view in Eclipse. If yes, could you please guide me on how to proceed?

Thanks in advance for your support!

entry.title: Re: Restriction outside Planned Protection
entry.content:
Hi Bpasi,
"Restriction outside planned protection" is a bit more difficult to explain with the example of the Advent calendar. However, I will try ...
For the other settings I've described how the advent calendar would work, if there is the setting "no restriction by own protection" or "restriction outside time bucket is".
However, all these examples explained this from the perspective of the restriction. For Supply Protection it usually doesn't matter how much is protected for you. This doesn't have a direct impact. Only the restrictions are interesting. "Restriction outside planned protection" is different, because here the own remaining protection is important.
If we now take the Advent Calendar I would state, "Restriction outside planned Protection" is the only setting, which takes care how much chocolate is behind the door of your Advent Calendar.
If there is one piece of chocolate for you behind this door, you most likely can eat it, because the restrictions are very low. 
However, if you now want to get more chocolate you must consider all other restrictions and here also the protection of lower priorities must be respected. So, it is much harder to get the 25th piece of chocolate.

entry.title: Finance + Procurement: From Siloes to a Single Source of Truth
entry.content:
Tariffs turn on a dime. Supply chains lurch. Close cycles compress. In this new normal, the most resilient enterprises win by aligning Procurement and Finance around a single source of truth—turning front-end spend decisions into back-end financial confidence.

Bottom line: When P2P (purchase-to-pay) excellence meets R2R (record-to-report) automation, organizations close faster, improve working capital, reduce risk, and make decisions with confidence.

Quick Takeaways

  • Procurement + Finance alignment is now a strategic imperative—measured by P&L impact, not just “negotiated savings.”
  • P2P manages how money leaves; BlackLine proves every transaction is properly accounted for—enabling a trusted, continuous close.
  • During disruption/tariff volatility, contract metadata (e.g., force majeure clauses) and intercompany allocations are mission critical.
  • Near real-time visibility into AP/AR/subledgers surfaces maverick spend before it hits quarterly results.
  • Cloud success isn’t “set it and forget it”—build a framework to absorb continual SaaS innovation (including GenAI).
  • The most overrated metric? “Negotiated savings” that never lands in EBITDA—focus on working capital, cash flow, and risk.

Why CPO–CFO Alignment Matters More Than Ever

CFOs have moved from “keepers of the books” to the strategic command center of the enterprise. At the same time, CPOs are stepping beyond cost control to resilience, risk, and growth enablement. Yet many organizations still operate on fragmented ERPs, manual close processes, and spotty data integrity—making alignment elusive.

Translation: If Procurement’s upstream decisions (suppliers, terms, rates) aren’t instantly visible to Finance downstream, you can’t drive working capital, free cash flow, or EBITDA improvements with confidence.

Two Sides of the Same Coin: P2P + R2R

  • P2P (SAP): Supplier onboarding → requisition → invoice processing → payment
  • R2R (BlackLine): Reconciliations, journal entries, variance analysis, intercompany accounting → continuous close

Together, they connect “how money leaves” with “proving every transaction is right”—a foundation for faster closes, fewer surprises, and better earnings visibility. BlackLine’s Studio 360 orchestrates multi‑ERP environments and unifies disparate financial data into a single source of truth, while native connectivity to the SAP ecosystem accelerates data flow and trust.

In the Real World: Disruptions, Tariffs & What-Ifs

When global supply disruption or tariff volatility hits, the winners are those who can answer, right now:

  • Which contracts carry force majeure protections?
  • Who absorbs the new costs—and where?
  • How should we allocate across legal entities for tax/tariff outcomes?

Best practice: Let SAP procurement tools expose rich contract metadata and negotiated terms to BlackLine for downstream financial operations—so AP, Accounting, and FP&A read off the same playbook. BlackLine’s intercompany capabilities then allocate invoices across entities correctly, reducing overpayments, tax leakage, and tariff misapplication.

Stop Maverick Spend Before It Hits the P&L

Right before Q4 close, surprise spend can derail profitability. With near real-time visibility across AP/AR/subledgers, BlackLine surfaces unplanned costs daily—early enough for action:

  • Validate PO compliance and pre‑negotiated rates
  • Optimize payment terms (e.g., push to next fiscal period if appropriate)
  • Pull forward revenue to balance profitability where feasible

This is confidence amid chaos—knowing sooner, deciding smarter.

Automation You Can Trust

BlackLine was built to automate at scale for enterprise and mega‑enterprise customers. One standout moment: in Exxon’s earnings remarks, the global CFO cited BlackLine’s automation impact, including tens of thousands of hours saved in manual workload (per the episode discussion). The power isn’t just saving time—it’s enabling leadership-grade trust in the numbers.

Pro tip: Treat SaaS as continuous value intake, not a one‑time implementation. Set a governance rhythm to adopt new features—especially as GenAI/agentic AI reshapes finance and procurement workflows.

Are Procurement Leaders Financial Stewards?

Yes—and not yet. The destination is clear: procurement’s contribution should be measured by P&L realities, working capital, supplier resilience, and risk reduction, not theoretical “avoided spend.” The gap: many teams still sit far from FP&A workflows. The leaders are changing this—partnering deeply with P&L owners and wiring processes so decisions land cleanly in Finance.

What “Great” Looks Like (A Practical Blueprint)

  1. Unify data: Stand up a shared single source of truth that connects SAP procurement decisions to BlackLine R2R processes.
  2. Expose contract intelligence: Make key clauses (e.g., force majeure) and payment terms machine‑visible downstream.
  3. Automate the close: Use BlackLine for recs, journals, variance, intercompany, and a continuous close cadence.
  4. Instrument the edge: Monitor maverick spend and non‑PO invoices in near real time to act before the quarter ends.
  5. Measure what matters: Shift from “negotiated savings” to cash, EBITDA, DPO/DSO, risk, and supplier resilience.
  6. Adopt continuously: Build a SaaS change framework to absorb ongoing enhancements and prepare for GenAI use cases.

The Future: Connected, Data‑Driven, Value‑Oriented

The days of Procurement judged solely on savings, and Finance on closing the books, are fading. The future is connected, AI‑literate, and relentlessly value‑oriented—where SAP + BlackLine create an operating system for trusted decisions across the enterprise.

Source

Based on the conversation from SAP’s The Future of Procurement podcast featuring Stuart Van Houten and Riyaz Samnani (BlackLine) with host Justin Morse—as provided in your webinar/podcast transcript.

https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/the-future-of-procurement/id1764078646?i=1000723863233

entry.title: Re: How to include Project System in Make-to-Stock proces...
entry.content:
Hello @Souhardhya 

Thanks for clarifying the scenario.

The Project System is separate from Make-to-Stock (MTS).

In MTS, production orders originate from planned independent requirements, and costs are assigned to cost centers and inventory rather than a WBS element.

The Project System in the Public Cloud is only supported for scenarios that are project-based, including:

  • Capital or internal projects scope item  Project Financial Control
  • Project procurement (BJ5)
  • Make-to-Order.

For a sugar mill that relies on forecasts and oversees stock levels, the recommended approach is to run standard MTS in PP without linking to PS. If project-specific cost tracking is necessary, then the process should be configured as project manufacturing

Below is some useful SAP Official documentation that will guide you to a better understanding

Manufacturing orders in MTS are settled to stock: For manufacturing orders settling to material (MAT), settlement is made to the stock of the produced product. SAP help Public Cloud. SAP Help Portal-Settlement Rules of Manufacturing Orders (Event-Based Posting Rules)

MTS learning event-driven WIP/variance and settlement in MTS SAP Learning Journey focused on analysing the settlement of final production orders in the MTS context. SAP Learning: Analysing the Settlement of a Finally Delivered Production Order

Repetitive/MTS in Public Cloud (when MTS is appropriate) SAP Learning Repetitive Manufacturing can be used for both MTS and MTO SAP Learning-Introducing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition – Manufacturing

Project System scope in Public Cloud (what PS is for), SAP Help to process status for enterprise projects/WBS (PS lifecycle in Public Cloud). SAP Help Portal-Processing Status for Projects and WBS Elements

Project-based PS scenarios: SAP Learning Project Control for Finance references Scope Item Project Control for Finance SAP Learning-Controlling Finance Projects

Overview of PS enterprise versus professional services projects in Public Cloud, focusing on the SAP Product Success blog. SAP Community-The two project control possibilities in SAP S/4HANA Cloud: Enterprise projects and professional services projects

Let me know if you need further information.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: How SAP Preferred Success’s Key Feature Analysis Empowers Customer Adoption
entry.content:
When it comes to SaaS success, adoption is everything. No matter how robust or innovative a product may be, it only delivers value when users embrace it. That’s where SAP Preferred Success steps in—specifically through its Key Feature Analysis (KFA) service, designed to bridge the gap between product potential and real-world usage.

In this blog, we’ll explore how KFA plays a crucial role in helping organizations not only measure adoption but accelerate it.

What is Key Feature Analysis?

Key Feature Analysis (KFA) is a data-driven service offered by SAP Preferred Success that identifies how end-users are interacting with a SaaS platform—particularly which features are being used, underused, or entirely ignored.

By leveraging user behavior data, KFA shines a spotlight on:

  • The most critical features aligned with business goals
  • Usage trends 
  • Opportunities to improve training, onboarding, or feature exposure

This analysis becomes a roadmap for deeper, smarter adoption.

Why Adoption Fails (And How KFA Solves It)

Common Roadblocks to Adoption:

  • Users are unaware of key features
  • Misaligned training or onboarding efforts
  • Overwhelming UI/UX without guided paths
  • Lack of leadership buy-in or communication
  • Teams revert to old processes out of habit

KFA addresses these challenges directly by turning assumptions into insights. Rather than guessing why adoption is lagging, organizations get clear data on where to focus their enablement efforts.

How KFA Helps Customers Drive Adoption

1. Identifies Feature Gaps

KFA uncovers which features are being underutilized and why. For example, if a core reporting tool is seldom accessed, the analysis might reveal a lack of visibility or confusion around its value. Preferred Success then works with stakeholders to reintroduce this feature in a meaningful way—whether through targeted training or UI adjustments.

2. Tailors Adoption Strategies

Not all users are the same. KFA segments usage by user roles, departments, or regions, allowing for customized enablement plans. For instance, sales teams may benefit from automation features, while support teams need deep training on case management tools.

3. Informs Data-Driven Training

Instead of generic sessions, KFA helps organizations design high-impact training programs focused on the features that matter most—and those that need the most attention. This targeted approach improves both adoption speed and retention.

4. Provides Ongoing Insights

Adoption isn’t a one-time event. KFA can be run periodically to track progress, fine-tune enablement strategies, and adjust to product updates or organizational changes. This continuous loop ensures long-term success.

5. Aligns Product Usage with Business Goals

Ultimately, adoption should lead to outcomes—whether it’s reduced churn, increased productivity, or improved customer service. KFA ensures that feature usage aligns directly with your business KPIs, enabling more strategic decisions and measurable ROI.

6. Reduces the Adoption Time Cycle 

By enabling organizations to leverage out-of-the-box (OOTB) functionalities and features, KFA helps shorten adoption cycles. This approach accelerates time-to-value and encourages a more innovative, technology-driven mindset.

Real Results, Real Impact

Customers leveraging Preferred Success’s KFA service have seen measurable improvements such as:

  • 20–30% increase in key feature adoption within 3 months
  • Reduced time-to-value for new users
  • Higher user satisfaction scores
  • More effective governance and change management

Whether you’re a SaaS provider looking to ensure customer retention or a company investing in new tools, KFA empowers your team with the insights needed to succeed.

Final Thoughts

SaaS adoption doesn’t happen by chance—it happens by design. SAP Preferred Success’s Key Feature Analysis transforms raw usage data into actionable insights, helping organizations maximize their investment and empower users to thrive.

If you’re looking to turn feature awareness into feature mastery, it’s time to make Key Feature Analysis part of your success strategy.

Interested in learning more?
Explore  how  SAP Preferred Success through Key Feature Analysis (KFA) and other tailored services can help you achieve your business goals.

entry.title: A Comprehensive Guide to Data Migration with the SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit
entry.content:
A Comprehensive Guide to Data Migration with the SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit

For End Users, Key Users, Dummies, and Consultants

Page 1: Introduction to Data Migration in SAP S/4HANA

Welcome to your complete guide to the SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit. Migrating data is one of the most critical activities in any SAP S/4HANA implementation project. It's the process of moving your essential business data—like customer information, product lists, and financial records—from your old system(s) into your new S/4HANA environment.

Think of it like moving into a new, state-of-the-art house. You can't start living there until you've moved in your furniture (your data). The SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit is your professional moving company, designed to make this process as smooth, efficient, and error-free as possible.

Who is this guide for?

  • For Dummies & End Users: We'll start with the basics, explaining what the tool is and why it's important, using simple analogies and clear steps.
  • For Key Users: You'll learn how to prepare your data, fill out the templates for your specific business area (like sales or procurement), and validate that the migrated data is correct.
  • For Consultants: You'll find technical details, information on advanced tools like the Migration Object Modeler, and a framework for managing the entire migration lifecycle.

This guide is based on the standard functionalities of the SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit 1, a powerful tool embedded directly within the S/4HANA solution2. It requires

no programming knowledge 3and provides a guided, step-by-step process for your migration journey4.

Page 2: Chapter 1 - Understanding the SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit

At its core, the Migration Cockpit is a tool designed to support

New Implementation scenarios 5—also known as a "Greenfield" approach—where you are setting up a fresh SAP S/4HANA system. It helps you load data from both old SAP systems (like ECC) and non-SAP systems6.

The tool is available for all SAP S/4HANA deployment models:

Cloud and On-Premise7.

Key Features and Value Proposition

The power of the Migration Cockpit lies in its simplicity and pre-packaged content. Here's what makes it so valuable:

  • Preconfigured Migration Content: SAP provides a huge library of "Migration Objects" for the most common data types, such as customers, suppliers, materials, bank data, open purchase orders, and G/L account balances8888.
  • Predefined Templates: For each migration object, the cockpit provides a ready-to-use Microsoft Excel XML file template9. You just need to extract your legacy data and paste it into this file in the correct format.
  • Automated Mapping: The tool automatically maps the columns in the template file to the correct fields in the S/4HANA database tables10. This saves countless hours of technical work.
  • Guided Process: The cockpit guides you through every step, from creating a project to validating and importing your data11.
  • No Programming Required: All migration programs are generated automatically by the system12. You don't need a developer to write custom code for loading data.
  • Data Validation: Before committing the data to the database, you can run a simulation to check for errors against your system's configuration and business rules1313. This ensures high data quality.

Page 3: The Three Pillars of the Migration Cockpit

The migration process can be understood through three main pillars, as shown in the architecture overview14141414.

  1. Data Provisioning (The "What"): This is your source data. You must first

extract data from your legacy systems (any system, SAP or non-SAP) and place it into the provided Microsoft Excel XML template files15151515. For On-Premise versions, there are more advanced options like staging tables, but for most users, the file-based approach is the starting point.

  1. Migration Tools (The "How"): This is the engine of the process.
    • SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit: This is the main user interface (a Fiori App) that you will use to manage the project, upload files, and monitor progress16.
    • SAP S/4HANA Migration Object Modeler (MOM): This is an advanced tool for consultants and developers. It is used when the standard migration objects are not enough, for example, if you need to add custom fields (like a special industry-specific field on the Material Master) or migrate completely custom data objects that are unique to your business17171717. This is available for on-premise and private cloud editions18.
  2. Content (The "Intelligence"): This is the pre-packaged value from SAP.
    • Preconfigured Migration Objects and Mapping: The library of business objects (e.g., "Customer," "Sales Order") that SAP has already defined for migration19.
    • Automated Program Generation: The underlying code that takes your file and posts it into S/4HANA is created automatically20.
    • Built-in Data Validation: The rules and checks that ensure your data is consistent and correct before loading21.

Page 4: Chapter 2 - The Migration Process: A Step-by-Step Guide

Let's walk through a typical migration process using the file-based approach. This process is generally the same whether you are migrating Materials, Customers, or G/L Postings22222222.

Prerequisite: You must have the necessary authorization roles assigned to your user in the SAP S/4HANA Fiori Launchpad. The role is typically SAP_BR_CONFIG_EXPERT_DATA_MIG.

Step 1: Access the Migration Cockpit

  1. Log in to your SAP S/4HANA Fiori Launchpad.
  2. Find and click on the Migrate Your Data - Migration Cockpit tile. This will launch the application.

Step 2: Create a New Migration Project

First, you need a project to organize your work. For example, you might create one project for "Phase 1 - Master Data" and another for "Phase 2 - Transactional Data."

  1. Inside the Migration Cockpit, click the Create button.
  2. You will be prompted to enter a Project Name. Let's call it Z_MASTER_DATA_LOAD_01.
  3. The system will ask for a Mass Transfer ID. This is a system-generated number used for tracking; you can typically leave it as default.
  4. Choose your Migration Scenario. For new implementations, this will generally be Migrate Data Using Staging Tables (for On-Premise, allowing database connection) or Migrate Data Using Files (for Cloud and On-Premise). We will use the file approach.
  5. Click

Create to finalize the project setup23.

Page 5: The Migration Process (Continued)

Step 3: Select Your Migration Objects

Now that you have a project, you need to tell the system what you want to migrate.

  1. With your project

Z_MASTER_DATA_LOAD_01 open, you will see a list of all available Migration Objects24. This list is extensive and categorized by business area.

  1. Scroll through the list or use the search bar to find the objects you need. For our example, let's select:
    • Customer (for Sales & Distribution)
    • Material (for Materials Management)
    • G/L account balance and open/line item (for Finance)
  2. Click the checkbox next to each object you want to include in your project25. You don't have to migrate everything at once. It's best practice to group similar objects together.

Step 4: Download and Populate the Templates

For each selected object, you need to download its unique template file.

  1. Select a migration object you've chosen, for example, Customer.
  2. Click the Download Template button. This will download an

XML file26, which will open in Microsoft Excel.

  1. Understanding the Template:
    • The file will have multiple tabs (worksheets).
    • The first tab, "Introduction," explains how to use the file. Read it carefully!
    • The "Field List" tab shows all possible fields you can populate for that object, indicating which are mandatory (marked with a *) and which are optional.
    • Subsequent tabs represent the different data structures for the object. For a Customer, you will see tabs for "General Data," "Company Code Data," "Sales Data," "Contact Persons," etc.
  2. Populate the Template: This is the most crucial step. You must extract the data from your legacy system and carefully copy-paste it into the corresponding columns in these worksheets.
    • Example: For the "General Data" sheet of the Customer template, you would fill in columns for Name, Address, City, Postal Code, Country, etc.
    • Important: Do not change the structure of the file, rename tabs, or delete columns.

Page 6: The Migration Process (Concluded)

Step 5: Upload and Prepare the Data File

Once your template is filled with data, it's time to upload it back into the cockpit.

  1. Go back to your migration project in the Fiori app.
  2. Select the Customer migration object.
  3. Click the Upload File button and choose the XML file you just populated.
  4. After uploading, the system will automatically Prepare and Validate the file. This step checks for structural integrity and basic data type consistency.

Step 6: Mapping and Simulation

This is where the system checks your data against its own configuration.

  1. After the preparation is complete, you will be taken to the Mapping Tasks screen. Here, the cockpit may ask you to confirm certain value mappings. For example, if your old system used "USA" for the United States and S/4HANA is configured to use "US," you would define that mapping rule here. For many standard values, the system can map them automatically.
  2. Once all mapping is confirmed, click

Simulate27. The system will now pretend to post the data without actually saving it. It will check against all business rules, such as:

    • Does the specified Company Code exist?
    • Is the specified Payment Term configured in the system?
    • Is the provided bank key valid?
  1. The simulation will return with a status:
    • Success: All records passed validation.
    • Errors: Some records failed. The system provides a detailed log explaining exactly which record, field, and value caused the error so you can fix it in your file and re-upload.

Step 7: Execute the Migration (Import)

This is the final step where the data is loaded into SAP S/4HANA.

  1. Once your simulation runs successfully with no errors, the Import button will become active.
  2. Click

Import28. The system will now perform the actual data posting.

  1. You can monitor the progress in real-time. Once complete, the cockpit will show you how many records were successfully created. You can then log into the relevant S/4HANA application (e.g., the "Manage Customer Master Data" Fiori app) to view and verify your newly migrated data.

Page 7: Chapter 3 - For Consultants: The Migration Object Modeler (MOM)

The standard content provided by SAP is extensive, but sometimes it's not enough. You might have custom fields or entire custom tables (known as "Z-tables" in the SAP world) that need to be migrated. This is where the

SAP S/4HANA Migration Object Modeler (MOM) comes in29.

Use Cases for the MOM:

  1. Enhancing Standard Objects: You need to add a new custom field to a standard object. For example, your business requires a "Loyalty Program ID" field on the Customer Master, which doesn't exist in the standard template. The MOM allows you to add this new field to the Customer object's structure and template30.
  2. Creating Custom Objects: You need to migrate data for a completely custom business object that is unique to your company, for example, a "Vehicle Fleet Management" table.
  3. Migrating Standard SAP Objects Not Yet in the Cockpit: Occasionally, SAP may not have delivered a migration object for a specific, less common data type. The MOM allows you to build your own object to cover this gap31.

How it Works (High-Level):

The MOM is a technical, design-time tool (transaction code LTMOM) available in the on-premise and private cloud editions. It provides a user interface to:

  • Define Source Structures: Specify the fields and structure of your incoming data (essentially, designing the template file).
  • Define Target Structures: Map your data to the target S/4HANA database tables and fields, including any custom "Z-fields."
  • Define Structure and Field Mappings: Create rules to translate source values to target values (e.g., IF source_field = 'A', THEN target_field = '10').
  • Generate the Migration Object: Once the design is complete, the MOM generates the runtime object that then becomes available for use in the main Migration Cockpit Fiori app.

Customizing Point (SPRO):

While the MOM itself is a transaction (LTMOM), the underlying custom fields (e.g., adding a new field to the customer master) must first be created using standard S/4HANA extensibility tools, often accessible through the Fiori Launchpad or via the SPRO transaction under Cross-Application Components -> General Application Functions -> Extensibility.

Page 8: Chapter 4 - Practical Exercise 1: Migrating Material Master Data (MM)

Let's apply the process to a real-world example. Your company is implementing SAP S/4HANA Materials Management (MM) and needs to migrate its list of raw materials from a legacy system.

Business Scenario:

You need to create 100 new raw materials (ROH material type) for your main manufacturing plant (1010) and storage location (101A). You need to define their basic data (description, unit of measure), purchasing data (purchasing group), and storage data.

Step-by-Step Exercise:

  1. Create Project: In the Migration Cockpit, create a project named Z_MM_DATA_LOAD.
  2. Select Object: Find and select the Material migration object.
  3. Download Template: Download the XML template file for the Material object.
  4. Populate Template:
    • Open the file in Excel.
    • In the Basic Data tab, you will fill in:
      • MATERIAL_NUMBER: e.g., RM-1001, RM-1002, ...
      • MATERIAL_DESCRIPTION: e.g., Steel Plate 5mm, Screw M6, ...
      • MATERIAL_TYPE: ROH for all entries.
      • BASE_UNIT_OF_MEASURE: PC (for pieces), KG (for kilograms), etc.
      • MATERIAL_GROUP: 00101 (e.g., for Metals).
    • In the Plant Data tab:
      • MATERIAL_NUMBER: RM-1001, RM-1002, ... (must match the basic data).
      • PLANT: 1010 for all entries.
      • PURCHASING_GROUP: 001 (e.g., Central Purchasing).
    • In the Storage Location Data tab:
      • MATERIAL_NUMBER: RM-1001, RM-1002, ...
      • PLANT: 1010.
      • STORAGE_LOCATION: 101A.
  5. Save and Upload: Save the XML file and upload it to the cockpit.
  6. Simulate: Run the simulation. A common error here is trying to use a Purchasing Group (e.g., 999) that has not been configured in S/4HANA yet. The simulation log will report this, and your configuration consultant will need to create it in SPRO (Materials Management -> Purchasing -> Create Purchasing Groups).
  7. Import: Once the simulation is successful, import the data.
  8. Verify: Go to the Manage Product Master Data Fiori app, search for one of your new materials (e.g., RM-1001), and confirm that all the views (Basic Data, Purchasing, Plant/Storage) have been created correctly.

Page 9: Chapter 5 - Practical Exercise 2: Migrating Open Purchase Orders (MM/FI)

Migrating open transactions is more complex than master data. This exercise shows how to load open purchase orders (POs) that were created in your legacy system but have not yet been fully delivered or invoiced.

Business Scenario:

You are going live with S/4HANA on January 1st. You have 50 open POs with your suppliers that need to be created in the new system so you can receive goods and process invoices against them.

Step-by-Step Exercise:

  1. Create Project: Use a new project, Z_TRANSACTION_LOAD, or add to an existing one.
  2. Select Object: Find and select the Purchase order (only open PO) migration object.
  3. Download Template: Download the corresponding template file.
  4. Populate Template: This template is more complex and has header and item details.
    • In the PO Header tab:
      • PO_NUMBER: You can enter your legacy PO number here for reference, but S/4HANA will assign a new number.
      • COMPANY_CODE: 1010.
      • PURCHASING_ORGANIZATION: 1010.
      • PURCHASING_GROUP: 001.
      • SUPPLIER_ID: The ID of the supplier in S/4HANA (this master data must be migrated first!).
    • In the PO Item tab:
      • PO_NUMBER: The same legacy PO number to link the item to the header.
      • PO_ITEM: 10, 20, etc.
      • MATERIAL_ID: The material number in S/4HANA (must be migrated first!).
      • QUANTITY: The remaining open quantity to be delivered.
      • PRICE: The price per unit.
      • PLANT: 1010.
  5. Save and Upload: Save the file and upload it.
  6. Simulate: Run the simulation. Common errors include referencing a Supplier or Material that does not exist, or using a combination of Purchasing Organization and Plant that is not configured.
  7. Import: Once successful, import the data.
  8. Verify: Use the Manage Purchase Orders Fiori app to find the newly created POs. Check that the supplier, materials, quantities, and prices match your legacy system. The PO will be ready for a goods receipt posting.

Page 10: Chapter 6 - The Future of Data Migration: Outlook

SAP is continuously enhancing the Migration Cockpit. The future direction focuses on providing more flexibility, automation, and integrated quality checks32323232.

Planned Functionalities and Enhancements:

  • More Data Provisioning Options:
    • Direct Access / Transfer: For migrations from an existing SAP ECC system, SAP plans to enable a direct connection to transfer data without the need for manual file extraction33333333. This significantly speeds up the process.
    • Staging Area: A dedicated staging database area where data can be loaded from various sources, cleaned, and validated before being moved into S/4HANA34. This is ideal for complex migration scenarios managed by a dedicated data team.
  • Enhanced Migration Process:
    • Automated Validation: More intelligent and automated checks during the simulation phase to catch errors earlier35.
    • Data Quality Analysis: Integrated tools to analyze the quality of source data even before migration begins, helping to identify and cleanse data in the legacy system36.
    • Auditable Solution: Enhanced logging and reporting to provide a clear audit trail of what data was migrated, when it was migrated, and by whom, ensuring compliance37.
    • Near Zero Downtime: For very large-scale migrations, SAP is working on solutions to minimize the business downtime required during the final data cutover38.

These future enhancements aim to make the migration process faster, more reliable, and less reliant on manual effort, transforming it into a more strategic part of the S/4HANA implementation journey.

Page 11: A Comprehensive Test Plan for Data Migration

For End Users, Key Users, Dummies, and Consultants

Introduction and Scope

This test plan provides a structured approach for testing and validating data migrated using the SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit. The scope of this plan is to verify the correctness, completeness, and usability of the migrated data within the target S/4HANA system. It does not cover the testing of business process configurations themselves, but rather ensures that the foundation data is solid.

Test Cycles:

Data migration testing should occur during multiple project phases:

  1. Unit Testing: The consultant or key user performs the initial data load for a single object (e.g., Customer) with a small data sample (1-10 records) to ensure the technical process works.
  2. System Integration Testing (SIT): Multiple objects are loaded in sequence (e.g., Cost Centers, then G/L Accounts, then Open Invoices) to test dependencies. A larger, sanitized data set is used.
  3. User Acceptance Testing (UAT): Business users are given the migrated data and asked to perform their daily tasks in the S/4HANA system to validate it in a real-world context. This uses a nearly full data load.

Test Tools:

  • SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit: For executing the loads and checking logs.
  • SAP S/4HANA Fiori Apps / SAP GUI: For validating the data post-migration.
  • Microsoft Excel: For comparing source data files against post-migration data extracts.

Page 12: Test Scenario 1: Master Data Integrity (MM & SD)

Objective: To verify that fundamental master data for Materials Management (MM) and Sales & Distribution (SD) has been migrated correctly.

Test Case ID: DM_UAT_MM_001

  • Description: Verify migrated Material Master data for a finished good.
  • Pre-conditions:
    1. The Material migration object has been loaded successfully.
    2. The user has access to the Manage Product Master Data Fiori app.
  • Test Steps:
    1. From the source data file, pick a specific finished good material number (e.g., FG-2055).
    2. Open the Manage Product Master Data app in S/4HANA.
    3. Search for material FG-2055.
    4. Verify that the Basic Data is correct: Description, Base Unit of Measure, Material Group.
    5. Verify that the Sales Data is correct: Sales Org, Distribution Channel, Delivering Plant.
    6. Verify that the MRP Data is correct: MRP Type, MRP Controller.
  • Expected Results: All data points in S/4HANA for material FG-2055 must exactly match the data provided in the source file. The material should be fully usable for creating a sales order.
  • Actual Results: [ ] Pass [ ] Fail

Test Case ID: DM_UAT_SD_001

  • Description: Verify migrated Customer Master data, including company code and sales area data.
  • Pre-conditions:
    1. The Customer migration object has been loaded successfully.
    2. The user has access to the Manage Customer Master Data Fiori app.
  • Test Steps:
    1. From the source data file, pick a specific customer (e.g., CUST-100200).
    2. Open the Manage Customer Master Data app.
    3. Search for customer CUST-100200.
    4. Verify General Data: Name, full address, and contact information.
    5. Verify Company Code Data: Reconciliation Account, Payment Terms.
    6. Verify Sales Area Data: Shipping Conditions, Partner Functions (e.g., Ship-to, Bill-to).
  • Expected Results: The customer record exists and is complete. All details match the source file. The customer can be used to create a sales order in the system.
  • Actual Results: [ ] Pass [ ] Fail

Page 13: Test Scenario 2: Financial Data Migration (FI)

Objective: To verify that financial master data and opening balances have been loaded correctly and are in balance.

Test Case ID: DM_UAT_FI_001

  • Description: Verify migrated G/L Account opening balances.
  • Pre-conditions:
    1. Migration objects for G/L Account Master and G/L account balance and open/line item have been loaded successfully.
    2. The user has access to the Display G/L Account Balances Fiori app.
  • Test Steps:
    1. From the source data file for G/L balances, identify a specific G/L account (e.g., 10010000 - Bank Account). Note its balance and currency.
    2. In S/4HANA, open the Display G/L Account Balances app.
    3. Enter the G/L account, company code, and fiscal year corresponding to the migration cutover date.
    4. Execute the report.
    5. Compare the closing balance shown in the report with the balance from the source file.
    6. Repeat this for at least one asset, one liability, and one equity account.
  • Expected Results: The balance for the G/L account in S/4HANA exactly matches the provided legacy balance. The overall trial balance (debits vs. credits) for all migrated G/L balances must be zero.
  • Actual Results: [ ] Pass [ ] Fail

Test Case ID: DM_UAT_FI_002

  • Description: Verify migrated Accounts Receivable (AR) open items for a customer.
  • Pre-conditions:
    1. The Customer and Accounts receivable open item migration objects have been loaded.
    2. The user has access to the Manage Customer Line Items Fiori app.
  • Test Steps:
    1. From the AR open items source file, choose a customer (e.g., CUST-100200) and note their open invoices (invoice numbers, dates, amounts).
    2. In S/4HANA, open the Manage Customer Line Items app.
    3. Enter the customer number and company code, and select "Open Items."
    4. Execute the report.
    5. Compare the list of open invoices displayed in S/4HANA with the list from the source file. Check document numbers (if mapped), posting dates, and amounts.
  • Expected Results: Every open invoice from the legacy system exists in S/4HANA for the correct customer with the correct amount and due date. The total AR balance for the customer matches the legacy system.
  • Actual Results: [ ] Pass [ ] Fail

Page 14: Test Scenario 3: Cross-Module Data Dependencies (PP/MM)

Objective: To ensure data that relies on other data objects has been migrated correctly and that the relationships are intact. A classic example is the Bill of Material (BOM).

Test Case ID: DM_UAT_PP_001

  • Description: Verify a migrated Bill of Material (BOM) for a finished good.
  • Pre-conditions:
    1. The Material migration object has been loaded for all finished goods and raw materials.
    2. The Bill of material migration object has been loaded successfully.
    3. The user has access to the Maintain Bill of Material app.
  • Test Steps:
    1. From your source data, select a finished good that has a BOM (e.g., FG-2055). Note its components and their quantities (e.g., 1x RM-1001, 4x RM-1002).
    2. In S/4HANA, open the Maintain Bill of Material app.
    3. Enter the parent material (FG-2055), the plant (1010), and the BOM usage (1 for Production).
    4. Display the BOM.
    5. Verify that all component materials are listed correctly.
    6. Verify that the quantity for each component is correct.
    7. Verify that the unit of measure for each component is correct.
  • Expected Results: The BOM in S/4HANA is an exact replica of the BOM from the legacy system. The system can successfully "explode" the BOM for a production planning scenario.
  • Actual Results: [ ] Pass [ ] Fail

Page 15: Test Scenario 4: Error Handling and Data Validation

Objective: To ensure the migration process correctly identifies and reports errors when provided with bad data. This is a negative test case.

Test Case ID: DM_SIT_VALIDATION_001

  • Description: Test the system's response to a template with a missing mandatory field.
  • Pre-conditions:
    1. A migration project is active.
    2. You have a populated Material template.
  • Test Steps:
    1. Take a valid Material template file.
    2. Find a mandatory field, for example, BASE_UNIT_OF_MEASURE.
    3. Delete the value from this field for one of the rows in the template.
    4. Save and upload the file to the Migration Cockpit.
    5. Run the Simulate step.
  • Expected Results: The simulation must fail. The migration cockpit should display a clear error message in the logs, indicating that the BASE_UNIT_OF_MEASURE is a required field and is missing for the specific record. The data should not be imported.
  • Actual Results: [ ] Pass [ ] Fail

Test Case ID: DM_SIT_VALIDATION_002

  • Description: Test the system's response to data that violates a configuration rule.
  • Pre-conditions:
    1. A migration project is active.
    2. You have a populated Customer template.
    3. The Payment Term Z999 does not exist in S/4HANA configuration.
  • Test Steps:
    1. Take a valid Customer template file.
    2. In the Company Code Data tab, for one of the customers, enter Z999 in the PAYMENT_TERMS column.
    3. Save and upload the file to the Migration Cockpit.
    4. Run the Simulate step.
  • Expected Results: The simulation must fail for that specific record. The log should show an error message stating that "Payment term Z999 is not defined in company code XXXX." The record should not be imported.
  • Actual Results: [ ] Pass [ ] Fail

Page 16: Test Plan Sign-Off

This section should be used to formally document the completion and outcome of the data migration testing cycles.

Test Cycle: (e.g., UAT - Finance)

Overall Summary:

(Provide a brief summary of the testing activities, e.g., "UAT testing for FI master data and open items was conducted from Sept 15-20. A total of 25 test cases were executed.")

Test Results:

  • Total Test Cases Executed:
  • Test Cases Passed:
  • Test Cases Failed:

Outstanding Defects/Issues:

(List any critical or major defects that remain open and need to be resolved before go-live.)

Recommendation:

Based on the results above, the test team provides the following recommendation:

  • [ ] Approval for Go-Live: The migrated data is of sufficient quality for production use.
  • [ ] Approval with Conditions: Go-Live is approved pending the resolution of the outstanding issues listed above.
  • [ ] Not Approved: The migrated data has critical defects, and a further test cycle is required after fixes are applied.

Sign-Off:
